title: How Can The Graph Be Used

content.question: A rod is at rest on a flat, horizontal surface. One end of the rod is attached to a pivot, and the rod may freely rotate around the pivot if acted upon by a net external torque, as shown in Figure 1. In an experiment, the rod is initially at rest and student exerts a net torque on the rod. Data are collected to create a graph of the rod’s angular acceleration as a function of time, as shown in Figure 2. Frictional forces are considered to be negligible. How can the student use the graph to determine the angular momentum of the rod at <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: Determine the average angular acceleration from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and multiply the result by the rotational inertia of the rod.

Determine the area bound by the curve and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and multiply the result by the rotational inertia of the rod.

Determine the average slope of the curve from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and multiply the result by the rotational inertia of the rod.

Multiply the angular acceleration at <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> by the rotational inertia of the rod.

content.answer: Determine the area bound by the curve and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and multiply the result by the rotational inertia of the rod.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
